title: Jean-Luc Pépin
text:
Jean-Luc Pepin, (November 1, 1924 – September 5, 1995) was a <a href="Canadians">Canadian</a> academic, politician and <a href="Canadian%20Cabinet">Cabinet</a> minister.
Political biography.
Pepin was a political science <a href="professor">professor</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Ottawa">University of Ottawa</a> when he was first elected to the <a href="House%20of%20Commons%20of%20Canada">House of Commons of Canada</a> in the <a href="1963%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1963 election</a> as a <a href="Liberal%20Party%20of%20Canada">Liberal</a> <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28Canada%29">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) from <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>.
From 1965 to 1972, he served in the cabinets of <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Canada">Prime Ministers</a> <a href="Lester%20B.%20Pearson">Lester B. Pearson</a> and <a href="Pierre%20Trudeau">Pierre Trudeau</a> in various capacities, including Minister of Mines and Minister of Industry, Trade and Commerce overseeing the decision to have Canada adopt the <a href="metric%20system">metric system</a>.
He lost his <a href="Legislative%20seat">seat</a> in the <a href="1972%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1972 election</a>, and retired from public life until 1975 when Trudeau appointed him to chair the Anti-Inflation Board.
In 1977, he and former <a href="Premier%20of%20Ontario">Premier of Ontario</a> <a href="John%20Robarts">John Robarts</a> were appointed to head the "Task Force on Canadian Unity". This task force was created by the federal government as a response to the election of the "<a href="Parti%20Qu%C3%A9b%C3%A9cois">Parti Québécois</a>", which seeks <a href="Quebec%20sovereignty%20movement">political independence for Quebec</a> in the <a href="1976%20Quebec%20general%20election">1976 provincial election</a>.
The task force issued a report in 1979 that recommended entrenching language rights in the <a href="Canadian%20Constitution">Canadian Constitution</a>, and for the reduction of federal powers in all areas but economic management. The Task Force also recommended the replacement of the <a href="Senate%20of%20Canada">Senate of Canada</a> with a "Council of the Federation" whose members would be appointed by provincial governments, and to grant the provinces a say in appointments to the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Canada">Supreme Court of Canada</a>. Most of these recommendations were rejected by the Government of Canada, and did not make their way into the new Constitution that was enacted in 1982.
After a seven-year absence, Pepin returned to the House of Commons in the <a href="1979%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1979 election</a>. When the Liberals returned to power after the <a href="1980%20Canadian%20federal%20election">1980 election</a>, he became <a href="Minister%20of%20Transport%20%28Canada%29">Minister of Transport</a> until 12 August 1983. Later, he became a <a href="Minister%20of%20State%20%28Canada%29">Minister of State</a> to the Department of External Affairs and <a href="Minister%20responsible%20for%20the%20Francophonie%20%28Canada%29">Minister responsible for La Francophonie</a>.
Later life.
Following heart surgery, he retired from politics in 1984, and returned to academia as a fellow at the <a href="University%20of%20Ottawa">University of Ottawa</a>'s Institute on Public Policy.
In 1977, he was made a Companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20Canada">Order of Canada</a>. He was bestowed the title, The <a href="Right%20Honourable">Right Honourable</a> in 1992.
Archives.
There is a Jean-Luc Pepin <a href="fonds">fonds</a> at <a href="Library%20and%20Archives%20Canada">Library and Archives Canada</a>.
